awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Building students' data literacy through the co-design of curriculum by mathematics and art teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to enact and study a process in which middle school teachers of mathematics and visual arts co-design and teach activities that combine math and art to teach data science. Many existing efforts to promote data literacy are grounded in mathematical concepts of central tendency and variation, and typically  are narrowly focused in single subject domains. Taking an art-based perspective on data science has the potential to promote student relevance, accessibility, engagement, reasoning, and meaning-making with data science. Moreover, visualization technology has advanced to a degree that the relation between the information in data and visual aesthetic can be leveraged easily. To explore the opportunity this offers, research on this project will examine how to equip teachers to develop such interdisciplinary pedagogical approaches to cultivate their students' data literacy. This exploratory project will provide support for 12 teachers during summer workshops and during the school year as these teachers implement their co-designed units in their classrooms. The work addresses the following questions: (1) How do we support effective co-design of data literacy units among art teachers, mathematics teachers, and researchers? (2) How are teachers able to use the unit materials in their classrooms to engage students in data literacy? And (3) How does an art-based approach support students' data literacy? Answers to these questions will build an understanding of how to support interdisciplinary curriculum design collaborations among researchers and teachers. They will also show how art-integrated, maker-oriented activities can support middle school learners' data literacy development; and how to design technologies that are accessible and powerful to teachers and learners in these interdisciplinary environments. 

Through summer workshops and year-round design collaborations, the project will iteratively design, test and refine four units for middle school classrooms, including activities, tools, and assessments, to promote students' data literacy. Data will be collected from co-design sessions as well as classroom-enactments, and will include observations, video/audio recordings, student- and teacher-generated artifacts, and pre and post assessments of students' knowledge and self-efficacy. Mixed methods analyses of these data, and syntheses of findings across participants, classroom enactments, and project years, will explore effective ways to support co-design among art teachers, mathematics teachers, and researchers; and the impact of art-integrated activities on students' data literacy.  This project will reach 12 teachers and their students across 6 New York city schools. By building capacity and knowledge about how to initiate and sustain teachers' interdisciplinary curriculum collaborations, the project will have broader impact. Refined project materials, including pedagogical approaches, toolkits and adaptable classroom activities, will be disseminated to facilitate classroom adoption by other educators who wish to undertake similar art-integrated data literacy curriculum design collaborations, and will thus ultimately broaden participation in data science among diverse youth within and beyond New York City.

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, cross-institutional researchers partnered with teachers of mathematics and various arts domains to co-design interdisciplinary data literacy curricula. Over the course of 3 years, the project engaged 10 teachers from 4 different schools across 3 U.S. states. Through our co-design process, we explored the following research questions:

  • How do we support effective co-design of data literacy units among art teachers, mathematics teachers, and researchers?
  • How are teachers able to use the unit materials in their classrooms to engage students in data literacy?
  • How does an art-based approach support students? data literacy?

The project resulted in four units that integrated data and the arts in the following ways:

Photoessays: Students explored data measuring healthy places, then used photography and creative writing to document and convey their personal perspectives on indicators of the health of their own communities.

Comics: Students analyzed graphs of their class?s responses to a survey about friendship beliefs and experiences and created digital comics to convey personal reflections about their own experiences in relation to their class data.

Dance: Students interpreted data visualizations on issues of their choice (e.g., employment, environment, health), then choreographed dances to communicate about those data and their implications.

Collage: Students critiqued informational texts and analyzed public data about time use, and produced digital collages with found imagery to communicate arguments about what their own personally-collected time use data says about them.

Through mixed methods analysis of student- and teacher-generated artifacts, interviews with teachers and students, and documentation of our co-design process, we found several affordances of arts-integrated approach to data literacy education. For example, artistic media can allow students new ways to make sense of and to represent statistical concepts (e.g., dancers using their relative body positions to contrast numbers in different categories, or a trend changing over time). As well, using art to generate data also empowered students with accessible ways to tell stories with data about their communities to external audiences (e.g., students using photography to raise critical awareness of issues and assets in their communities). In addition, art provided a way for students to reflect on personal meanings behind data, and to thus engage in socioemotional reasoning through data reasoning and artistic representation (e.g., students creating comic narratives to comment on their personal and peers? experiences given trends in classroom friendship data).

We also encountered challenges that suggest areas for future research and development. First, co-design with cross-subject teachers, and moreover, implementing interdisciplinary units in schools posed logistical challenges that varied greatly depending on schools? existing infrastructural support for such curriculum (e.g., time for teachers to co-design, encouragement from school administration to pursue interdisciplinary curriculum, strictness of adherence to standardized testing, pacing in each subject etc.). As the project entered its third year, and some teachers separated from their initial partnerships to teach interdisciplinary units on their own, we had to develop ways to address the need for teachers to be supported in the subjects that were not within their realm of expertise (i.e., data literacy support for the ELA teacher). Conflicts in instructional goals between subject areas, and lack of subject-specific expertise, led to wavering to find the balance between meaningful artistic expression and meaningful data reasoning.

Together, findings from this project show the value of arts-integrated data literacy for promoting students? engagement and critical sensemaking with and about data. They also point to the need for careful scaffolding and support for both teachers and students. 

By creating curriculum in close collaboration with teachers, who may continue to refine and teach with these curricula, tools and pedagogical approaches throughout their careers, this project?s outputs have the potential to reach far more students beyond those who participated in our research. It offers an example of how data literacy education can be integrated into subjects outside of mathematics, and sheds light on the specific challenges and barriers to doing so in school contexts, which may inform other similar efforts to integrate data literacy into other subjects. By furthermore exploring art as an entrypoint into data science, this project also has a potential broader impact on issues of equity in data science education, as it makes data more accessible and relatable to a more diverse set of learners.
